MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of dir_reader: ```c static ssize_t dir_reader (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max) { DIR *dir = cls; struct dirent *e; int res; if (max < 512) return 0; (void) pos; /* 'pos' is ignored as function return next one single entry per call. */ do { e = readdir (dir); if (e == NULL) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_OF_STREAM; } while (e->d_name[0] == '.'); res = snprintf (buf, max, "%s
", e->d_name, e->d_name); if (0 >= res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; return (ssize_t) res; } ``` Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c if (max < (size_t) res) return MHD_CONTENT_READER_END_WITH_ERROR; ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: snprintf returns the number of characters that would have been written. If res == max the output was truncated (res >= max indicates truncation) but the code tests only max < (size_t)res, so it fails to detect the res == max case. The function then returns res (the would-be length) while only max-1 bytes plus a NUL were actually written into buf; a caller that uses the returned length may read past the buffer bounds, causing an out-of-bounds access.
